title: 111_hr6531
content: The Act is titled the "Equitable Treatment of Investors Act" and includes amendments to the Securities Investor Protection Act of 1970. The Securities Investor Protection Act of 1970 is amended to define 'net equity' as the dollar amount owed to a customer based on their account positions. The Securities Investor Protection Act of 1970 is amended to define 'net equity' as the dollar amount owed to a customer based on their account positions, including futures contracts and options on futures contracts held in a portfolio margining account. This calculation includes property collateralizing the positions, minus any customer indebtedness to the debtor, plus any payment made by the customer to the debtor. The trustee may approve indebtedness to the debtor within a specified period, not exceeding sixty days after notice. Claims for commodity futures contracts in a portfolio margining account or security futures contracts are treated as cash claims. "In determining net equity, accounts held by a customer in separate capacities are considered separate customers. Net equity is based on the information in the customer's last statement from the debtor." The provisions regarding customer accounts before the filing date include specific confirmations of positions, options, contracts, or indebtedness received after the last statement but before the filing date. There is a fraud exception for customers who were aware of fraudulent activity by the debtor or were involved in such activity. The debtor must have been registered with the SEC, known or should have known about fraudulent activity involving a customer, and failed to notify SIPC. The Securities Investor Protection Act prohibits a trustee from recovering property transferred by the debtor to a customer before the filing date unless the customer knew about the debtor's fraudulent activity or was involved in such activity. The Securities Investor Protection Act prohibits a trustee from recovering property transferred by the debtor to a customer before the filing date unless the customer knew about the debtor's fraudulent activity or was involved in such activity. Amendments to the Act include requirements for persons registered with the SEC to report fraudulent activity by the debtor to SIPC, the Commission, or law enforcement. Additionally, the appointment of trustees is addressed in the amendments. The Securities Investor Protection Act of 1970 is amended to include provisions for the appointment of a trustee and attorney for the liquidation of a debtor's business. The court will appoint suitable individuals selected by the Commission to serve in these roles. The Commission will provide the court with a list of candidates for the position of trustee and attorney for the debtor. The trustee must be disinterested, except for specific purposes approved by SIPC and the court. The trustee appointed must file a bond as required by law. The amendment made by paragraph (1) regarding the appointment of trustees and attorneys will take effect for those appointed after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE. The amendments made by section 2 will apply to ongoing or new liquidation proceedings under the Securities Investor Protection Act of 1970, except as provided in section 2(c)(2).
